Stephen G. Zimmer, Ph.D. Appendix 111
THE JOURNAL OF BIOLOGICAL CHEMISTRY C 1992 by The American Society for Biochemistry and Molecular Biology. L
267, No. I. laque of B. pp. 6. 1992 Printed in U.S.A :selected: NE41
ras Transformation of Cloned Rat Embryo Fibroblasts Results in Increased Rates of Protein Synthesis and Eukaryotic Initiation Factor 4E (oIF-4E) Phosphorylation
Линце вий
(Received for publication, January 17, 1992)
Carrie W. Rinker-Schaeffert, Vincent Austini, Stephen Zimmers, and Robert E. Rhoadsty From the Departments of Biochemistry and & Microbiology and Immunology, College of Medicine, University of Kentucky, Lexington, Kentucky 40536
T
Eukaryotic initiation factor 4E (eIF-4E) is a 25-kDa phosphoprotein that binds to the 7-methylguanosine cap of mRNA and acts, along with other elF-4 polypep- tides, to unwind mRNA secondary structure at the 5' terminus. Recent studies have indicated that eIF-4E acts as a protooncogene, but only in its phosphorylated state. In order to determine the role of elF-4E in on- cogenesis, we examined its regulation and expression in cloned rat embryo fibroblasts transformed with the Harvey ras (Ha-ras) oncogene. The expression of Ha- ras increased the rate of protein synthesis but did not increase the levels of eIF-4E mRNA or protein. How- ever, a dramatic increase (7-fold) in phosphate incor- poration into eIF-4E was observed. The percentage of eIF-4E in the phosphorylated state was the same in transfected and control cells, indicating that both phos- phorylation and dephosphorylation of eIF-4E were in- creased. Phosphopeptide mapping of elF-4E from > GREF T4 cells indicated a single site of phosphoryl- ation at Ser-53, which is the same as that identified previously in eIF-4E from reticulocytes and HeLa cells. These results indicate that p21"" is part of the signal transduction pathway leading to phosphorylation of oIF-4E. These findings also provide a potential mech- anism for cell transformation by p21"" which involves the preferential stimulation of translation of certain mRNAs.
The H-ros-1, K-ras-2, and N-ros genes encode a group of closely related 21-kDa membrane-associated proteins, termed p21"", which have been extensively characterized (Barbacid, 1987). p21 *** is localized on the inner leaflet of the plasma membrane and exhibits guanine nucleotide binding and or- > change activities which are characteristic of G proteins (Bourne et al., 1990). These properties suggest a role for p21"" in signal transduction across the cell membrane. p21"" in the GTP-bound state is active, whereas p21""-GDP is inactive (McCormick, 1989). Oncogenic ras genes are distinguished from their normal protooncogene counterparts by the pres- ence of one or more point mutations which stabilize the protein in an active complex with GTP. Expression of onco- genic p21"" is associated with increased cell proliferation, transformation, and differentiation (Durkin and Whitfield,
1989). However, despite extensive characterization of the biological effects of oncogenic p21"", its effectors and mech- anism of action remain unclear. 2
The eukaryotic translation initiation factor (oIF-4EVis a 25-kDa polypeptide that binds to the 5' cap of mRNA af both a free polypeptide and as part of a complex termed elF-4F which also contains elF-4A and a 220-kDa polypeptide. The elF-4F complex acts at the step wherein mRNA becomes bound to the 43 S initiation complex. This step has been ? shown to be rate-limiting for protein synthesis under normal (e.g. nonvirus-infected) cellular conditions (reviewed in So- nenberg, 1988; Rhoads, 1991a). Recent evidence suggests & critical role for eIF-4E in regulating the overall rate of protein synthesis. elf-yf can modulate
1
One way that the rate of protein synthesis can be modulated. is by the phosphorylation of GIF-45. elF-4E exists as a mix- ture of phosphorylated and unphosphorylated forms in a number of systems, the major site of phosphorylation being Ser-53 (reviewed in Rhoads, 1991b). Conditions which inhibit protein synthesis, such as heat shock (Duncan et al, 1987) and mitosis (Bonneau and Sonenberg, 1987), cause a decrease in the phosphorylation of eIF-4E. Conversely, an increase in eIF-4E phosphorylation has been correlated with stimulation of cells with numerous mitogens, including phorbol esters, serum, EGF, PDGF, and insulin (reviewed in Rhoads, 1991b). Closer inspection of this phenomenon reveals that it is the rate of elF-4E phosphorylation rather than the steady state level of phosphorylation that is best correlated with the rate of protein synthesis (Rychlik et al, 1990). Further evidence for rapid turnover of eIF-4E phosphate is provided by studies using okadaic acid which suggest a role for either proteiner phosphatase 1 or 2A (Rychlik et al, 1990; Donalson et al, 1991). It is not entirely clear how increased phosphorylation of eIF-4E increases the rate of protein synthesis, but insight into the mechanism is provided by in vitro studies which show that eIF-4E is only transferred to the 43 S initiation complex \ in the phosphorylated state (Joshi-Barve et al., 1990).
Another way that eIF-4E may affect the rate of protein synthesis is by its level of expression. Expression of antisense RNA to eIF-4E mRNA inhibits protein synthesis in direct proportion to the decrease in eIF-4E levels (De Benedetti et al., 1991), whereas increasing the level of eIF-4E results in a phenotype similar to cells transformed with classical onco- genes (Lazaris-Karatzas et al., 1990; De Benedetti and
. This work was supported by Research Grants GM20818 from the National Institute of General Medical Sciences and 3076 from the Council for Tobacco Research; Inc. The costs of publication of this article were defrayed in part by the payment of page charges. This article must therefore be hereby marked "advertisement" in accord- ance with 18 U.S.C. Section 1734 solely to indicate this fact.
1 To whom correspondence should be addressed 1
"The abbreviations used are: elF-4E, eukaryotic initiation factor 4E; EGF, epidermal growth factor; PDGF, platelet-derived growth factor, CREF, cloned rat embryo fibroblast(s): SDS-PAGE, sodium dodecyl sulfate-polyacrylamide gel electrophoresis; HPLC, high per- formance liquid chromatography; DMEM, Dulbecco's modified Ea- gle's medium; PCR, polymerase chain reaction.
1

ras Transformation of Cloned Rat Embryo Fibroblasts Results in
Increased Rates of Protein Synthesis and Eukaryotic Initiation Factor
4E (oIF-4E) Phosphorylation
Линце вий
(Received for publication, January 17, 1992)
Carrie W. Rinker-Schaeffert, Vincent Austini, Stephen Zimmers, and Robert E. Rhoadsty
From the Departments of Biochemistry and & Microbiology and Immunology, College of Medicine, University of Kentucky,
Lexington, Kentucky 40536
T
Eukaryotic initiation factor 4E (eIF-4E) is a 25-kDa
phosphoprotein that binds to the 7-methylguanosine
cap of mRNA and acts, along with other elF-4 polypep-
tides, to unwind mRNA secondary structure at the 5'
terminus. Recent studies have indicated that eIF-4E
acts as a protooncogene, but only in its phosphorylated
state. In order to determine the role of elF-4E in on-
cogenesis, we examined its regulation and expression
in cloned rat embryo fibroblasts transformed with the
Harvey ras (Ha-ras) oncogene. The expression of Ha-
ras increased the rate of protein synthesis but did not
increase the levels of eIF-4E mRNA or protein. How-
ever, a dramatic increase (7-fold) in phosphate incor-
poration into eIF-4E was observed. The percentage of
eIF-4E in the phosphorylated state was the same in
transfected and control cells, indicating that both phos-
phorylation and dephosphorylation of eIF-4E were in-
creased. Phosphopeptide mapping of elF-4E from
> GREF T4 cells indicated a single site of phosphoryl-
ation at Ser-53, which is the same as that identified
previously in eIF-4E from reticulocytes and HeLa cells.
These results indicate that p21"" is part of the signal
transduction pathway leading to phosphorylation of
oIF-4E. These findings also provide a potential mech-
anism for cell transformation by p21"" which involves
the preferential stimulation of translation of certain
mRNAs.
The H-ros-1, K-ras-2, and N-ros genes encode a group of
closely related 21-kDa membrane-associated proteins, termed
p21"", which have been extensively characterized (Barbacid,
1987). p21 *** is localized on the inner leaflet of the plasma
membrane and exhibits guanine nucleotide binding and or-
> change activities which are characteristic of G proteins
(Bourne et al., 1990). These properties suggest a role for p21""
in signal transduction across the cell membrane. p21"" in the
GTP-bound state is active, whereas p21""-GDP is inactive
(McCormick, 1989). Oncogenic ras genes are distinguished
from their normal protooncogene counterparts by the pres-
ence of one or more point mutations which stabilize the
protein in an active complex with GTP. Expression of onco-
genic p21"" is associated with increased cell proliferation,
transformation, and differentiation (Durkin and Whitfield,
1989). However, despite extensive characterization of the
biological effects of oncogenic p21"", its effectors and mech-
anism of action remain unclear.
The eukaryotic translation initiation factor (oIF-4EVis a
25-kDa polypeptide that binds to the 5' cap of mRNA af both
a free polypeptide and as part of a complex termed elF-4F
which also contains elF-4A and a 220-kDa polypeptide. The
elF-4F complex acts at the step wherein mRNA becomes
bound to the 43 S initiation complex. This step has been ?
shown to be rate-limiting for protein synthesis under normal
(e.g. nonvirus-infected) cellular conditions (reviewed in So-
nenberg, 1988; Rhoads, 1991a). Recent evidence suggests &
critical role for eIF-4E in regulating the overall rate of protein
synthesis. elf-yf can modulate
One way that the rate of protein synthesis can be modulated.
is by the phosphorylation of GIF-45. elF-4E exists as a mix-
ture of phosphorylated and unphosphorylated forms in a
number of systems, the major site of phosphorylation being
Ser-53 (reviewed in Rhoads, 1991b). Conditions which inhibit
protein synthesis, such as heat shock (Duncan et al, 1987)
and mitosis (Bonneau and Sonenberg, 1987), cause a decrease
in the phosphorylation of eIF-4E. Conversely, an increase in
eIF-4E phosphorylation has been correlated with stimulation
of cells with numerous mitogens, including phorbol esters,
serum, EGF, PDGF, and insulin (reviewed in Rhoads, 1991b).
Closer inspection of this phenomenon reveals that it is the
rate of elF-4E phosphorylation rather than the steady state
level of phosphorylation that is best correlated with the rate
of protein synthesis (Rychlik et al, 1990). Further evidence
for rapid turnover of eIF-4E phosphate is provided by studies
using okadaic acid which suggest a role for either proteiner
phosphatase 1 or 2A (Rychlik et al, 1990; Donalson et al,
1991). It is not entirely clear how increased phosphorylation
of eIF-4E increases the rate of protein synthesis, but insight
into the mechanism is provided by in vitro studies which show
that eIF-4E is only transferred to the 43 S initiation complex \
in the phosphorylated state (Joshi-Barve et al., 1990).
Another way that eIF-4E may affect the rate of protein
synthesis is by its level of expression. Expression of antisense
RNA to eIF-4E mRNA inhibits protein synthesis in direct
proportion to the decrease in eIF-4E levels (De Benedetti et
al., 1991), whereas increasing the level of eIF-4E results in a
phenotype similar to cells transformed with classical onco-
genes (Lazaris-Karatzas et al., 1990; De Benedetti and
. This work was supported by Research Grants GM20818 from the
National Institute of General Medical Sciences and 3076 from the
Council for Tobacco Research; Inc. The costs of publication of this
article were defrayed in part by the payment of page charges. This
article must therefore be hereby marked "advertisement" in accord-
ance with 18 U.S.C. Section 1734 solely to indicate this fact.

4E; EGF, epidermal growth factor; PDGF, platelet-derived growth
factor, CREF, cloned rat embryo fibroblast(s): SDS-PAGE, sodium
dodecyl sulfate-polyacrylamide gel electrophoresis; HPLC, high per-
formance liquid chromatography; DMEM, Dulbecco's modified Ea-
gle's medium; PCR, polymerase chain reaction.

ras Transformation of Cloned Rat Embryo Fibroblasts Results in Increased Rates of Protein Synthesis and Eukaryotic Initiation Factor 4E (oIF-4E) Phosphorylation

Carrie W. Rinker-Schaeffert, Vincent Austini, Stephen Zimmers, and Robert E. Rhoadsty From the Departments of Biochemistry and & Microbiology and Immunology, College of Medicine, University of Kentucky, Lexington, Kentucky 40536

Eukaryotic initiation factor 4E (eIF-4E) is a 25-kDa phosphoprotein that binds to the 7-methylguanosine cap of mRNA and acts, along with other elF-4 polypep- tides, to unwind mRNA secondary structure at the 5' terminus. Recent studies have indicated that eIF-4E acts as a protooncogene, but only in its phosphorylated state. In order to determine the role of elF-4E in on- cogenesis, we examined its regulation and expression in cloned rat embryo fibroblasts transformed with the Harvey ras (Ha-ras) oncogene. The expression of Ha- ras increased the rate of protein synthesis but did not increase the levels of eIF-4E mRNA or protein. How- ever, a dramatic increase (7-fold) in phosphate incor- poration into eIF-4E was observed. The percentage of eIF-4E in the phosphorylated state was the same in transfected and control cells, indicating that both phos- phorylation and dephosphorylation of eIF-4E were in- creased. Phosphopeptide mapping of elF-4E from > GREF T4 cells indicated a single site of phosphoryl- ation at Ser-53, which is the same as that identified previously in eIF-4E from reticulocytes and HeLa cells. These results indicate that p21"" is part of the signal transduction pathway leading to phosphorylation of oIF-4E. These findings also provide a potential mech- anism for cell transformation by p21"" which involves the preferential stimulation of translation of certain mRNAs.

The H-ros-1, K-ras-2, and N-ros genes encode a group of closely related 21-kDa membrane-associated proteins, termed p21"", which have been extensively characterized (Barbacid, 1987). p21 *** is localized on the inner leaflet of the plasma membrane and exhibits guanine nucleotide binding and or- > change activities which are characteristic of G proteins (Bourne et al., 1990). These properties suggest a role for p21"" in signal transduction across the cell membrane. p21"" in the GTP-bound state is active, whereas p21""-GDP is inactive (McCormick, 1989). Oncogenic ras genes are distinguished from their normal protooncogene counterparts by the pres- ence of one or more point mutations which stabilize the protein in an active complex with GTP. Expression of onco- genic p21"" is associated with increased cell proliferation, transformation, and differentiation (Durkin and Whitfield,
1989). However, despite extensive characterization of the biological effects of oncogenic p21"", its effectors and mech- anism of action remain unclear. 2

The eukaryotic translation initiation factor (oIF-4EVis a 25-kDa polypeptide that binds to the 5' cap of mRNA af both a free polypeptide and as part of a complex termed elF-4F which also contains elF-4A and a 220-kDa polypeptide. The elF-4F complex acts at the step wherein mRNA becomes bound to the 43 S initiation complex. This step has been ? shown to be rate-limiting for protein synthesis under normal (e.g. nonvirus-infected) cellular conditions (reviewed in So- nenberg, 1988; Rhoads, 1991a). Recent evidence suggests & critical role for eIF-4E in regulating the overall rate of protein synthesis. elf-yf can modulate

One way that the rate of protein synthesis can be modulated. is by the phosphorylation of GIF-45. elF-4E exists as a mix- ture of phosphorylated and unphosphorylated forms in a number of systems, the major site of phosphorylation being Ser-53 (reviewed in Rhoads, 1991b). Conditions which inhibit protein synthesis, such as heat shock (Duncan et al, 1987) and mitosis (Bonneau and Sonenberg, 1987), cause a decrease in the phosphorylation of eIF-4E. Conversely, an increase in eIF-4E phosphorylation has been correlated with stimulation of cells with numerous mitogens, including phorbol esters, serum, EGF, PDGF, and insulin (reviewed in Rhoads, 1991b). Closer inspection of this phenomenon reveals that it is the rate of elF-4E phosphorylation rather than the steady state level of phosphorylation that is best correlated with the rate of protein synthesis (Rychlik et al, 1990). Further evidence for rapid turnover of eIF-4E phosphate is provided by studies using okadaic acid which suggest a role for either proteiner phosphatase 1 or 2A (Rychlik et al, 1990; Donalson et al, 1991). It is not entirely clear how increased phosphorylation of eIF-4E increases the rate of protein synthesis, but insight into the mechanism is provided by in vitro studies which show that eIF-4E is only transferred to the 43 S initiation complex \ in the phosphorylated state (Joshi-Barve et al., 1990).

Another way that eIF-4E may affect the rate of protein synthesis is by its level of expression. Expression of antisense RNA to eIF-4E mRNA inhibits protein synthesis in direct proportion to the decrease in eIF-4E levels (De Benedetti et al., 1991), whereas increasing the level of eIF-4E results in a phenotype similar to cells transformed with classical onco- genes (Lazaris-Karatzas et al., 1990; De Benedetti and

Section 1734 solely to indicate this fact.
